General course objectives:
General course objectives
To equip you with the necessary theoretical and numerical tools to understand the diverse emergent phenomena originating from strong light-matter interaction. The course will provide you with basics on optical properties of two-dimensional materials and you will be introduced to research-level methodologies to treat their strong interaction with classical and quantum light.
Learning objectives:
A student who has met the objectives of the course will be able to:
List the relevant symmetries in 2D materials
Construct tight-binding models for most representative 2D materials
Model the optical response of 2D Materials
Derive Electric and Magnetic Fields in quantized form
List and explain the different gauge choices
Derive Light-matter coupling from local charge conservation
Explain the consequence of periodic laser driving of materials
Apply Floquet theory to engineer band structures in 2D materials
Model the formation of composite polaritons
Content: Tight-binding models of representative 2D materials, Electronic structure and valley degrees of freedom, Optical linear response theory, Excitons. Light-Matter interaction Hamiltonians, gauge freedom, Floquet theory, the concept of Polaritons, low-energy Quantum electrodynamics (QED), basics of Cavity material engineering.
Course literature: Tailored notes from teacher and references to research papers.
